learning_outcomes: Master the use of inversion for rhetorical effect
Use cleft sentences to focus on specific information
Identify formal contexts where these structures are appropriate
Enhance stylistic precision in written and spoken English

content.stimulus_en: I have never seen such a beautiful sunset.
content.correct_answer: Never have I seen such a beautiful sunset.
content.explanation: When starting with 'Never', use inversion: Never + auxiliary + subject + verb.

content.stimulus_en: They rarely go out during the week.
content.correct_answer: Rarely do they go out during the week.
content.explanation: Inversion with 'Rarely' requires the auxiliary 'do/does/did'.

options.text: Seldom we have heard such a moving speech.
Seldom have we heard such a moving speech.
Seldom we had heard such a moving speech.

content.correct_answer: o2
content.explanation: 'Seldom' requires inversion of the auxiliary.

content.stimulus_en: He didn't know that the police were watching him.
content.correct_answer: Little did he know that the police were watching him.
content.explanation: 'Little' meaning 'not at all' triggers inversion.

content.stimulus_en: Hardly ________ the meeting started when the phone rang. (had / did)
content.correct_answer: had
content.explanation: Hardly... when usually takes the Past Perfect.

content.prompt_es: Usa 'No sooner' para unir las frases:
content.stimulus_en: I sat down. Then the doorbell rang.
content.correct_answer: No sooner had I sat down than the doorbell rang.
content.explanation: 'No sooner' is followed by inversion and 'than'.

options.text: Not only did she win, but she also broke the record.
Not only she won, but she also broke the record.

content.correct_answer: a
content.explanation: 'Not only' at the start requires inversion in the first clause.

content.stimulus_en: You must not press this button.
content.correct_answer: Under no circumstances must you press this button.
content.explanation: 'Under no circumstances' is a strong negative expression requiring inversion.

content.stimulus_en: The suspect never admitted his guilt.
content.correct_answer: At no time did the suspect admit his guilt.
content.explanation: 'At no time' replaces 'never' and triggers inversion.

content.prompt_es: Completa con la forma invertida de 'only then':
content.stimulus_en: She read the letter. Then she understood. -> Only then ________ she understand.
content.correct_answer: did
content.explanation: 'Only then' requires inversion of the main verb's auxiliary.

content.stimulus_en: I love the music in this film.
content.correct_answer: It is the music in this film that I love.
content.explanation: Structure: It + be + [emphasized part] + that/who...

content.prompt_es: Transforma en 'What-cleft' para enfatizar 'a good rest':
content.stimulus_en: I need a good rest.
content.correct_answer: What I need is a good rest.
content.explanation: A 'What-cleft' starts with 'What' + clause + 'is/was' + noun phrase.

options.text: What she did was she called the police.
What she did was call the police.
What did she do was call the police.

content.correct_answer: o2
content.explanation: Structure: What + subject + do + be + base form/to-infinitive.

content.stimulus_en: I only want a glass of water.
content.correct_answer: All I want is a glass of water.
content.explanation: 'All' can be used as a pseudo-cleft meaning 'the only thing'.

content.stimulus_en: The Beatles became famous in the 1960s.
content.correct_answer: It was in the 1960s that The Beatles became famous.
content.explanation: You can emphasize prepositional phrases with It-clefts.

content.stimulus_en: We met in Paris. -> ________ was in Paris that we met.
content.correct_answer: It
content.explanation: It-clefts always start with 'It'.

content.prompt_es: Usa una 'What-cleft' para enfatizar la acción 'broke the window':
content.stimulus_en: John broke the window.
content.correct_answer: What John did was break the window.
content.explanation: Pseudo-cleft focusing on the action.

options.text: The reason why I'm here is to help.
I'm here because I want to help.

content.correct_answer: a
content.explanation: 'The reason why...' is a type of cleft structure.

content.stimulus_en: I hate his arrogance.
content.correct_answer: It is his arrogance that I hate.
content.explanation: Standard It-cleft focusing on the object.

content.stimulus_en: ________ that annoys me is his lack of punctuality.
content.correct_answer: The thing
content.explanation: 'The thing that' is a common pseudo-cleft starter.

content.prompt_es: Reescribe el primer condicional usando inversión:
content.stimulus_en: If you should need any help, let me know.
content.correct_answer: Should you need any help, let me know.
content.explanation: Inversion in Type 1: Should + subject + verb.

content.prompt_es: Reescribe el segundo condicional usando inversión:
content.stimulus_en: If I were you, I would accept the offer.
content.correct_answer: Were I you, I would accept the offer.
content.explanation: Inversion in Type 2: Were + subject + ...

content.prompt_es: Reescribe el tercer condicional usando inversión:
content.stimulus_en: If he had known, he would have come.
content.correct_answer: Had he known, he would have come.
content.explanation: Inversion in Type 3: Had + subject + past participle.

options.text: Had not he missed the train, he'd be here.
Had he not missed the train, he'd be here.
If had he not missed the train, he'd be here.

content.correct_answer: o2
content.explanation: In negative inversion, 'not' comes after the subject.

content.stimulus_en: If they played better, they would win.
content.correct_answer: Were they to play better, they would win.
content.explanation: For action verbs in Type 2, use Were + subject + to-infinitive.

content.stimulus_en: ________ I to win the lottery, I would travel the world.
content.correct_answer: Were
content.explanation: Formal inversion for hypothetical situations.

options.text: Should the weather improve, we'll go out.
If the weather should improve, we'll go out.

content.correct_answer: a
content.explanation: Inversion is generally more formal than 'if'.

content.prompt_es: Reescribe: 'If the company had been more careful...'
content.stimulus_en: If the company had been more careful, they wouldn't be in debt.
content.correct_answer: Had the company been more careful, they wouldn't be in debt.
content.explanation: Third conditional inversion.

content.prompt_es: Completa: ________ you have any questions, don't hesitate to ask.
content.correct_answer: Should
content.explanation: Inversion for polite instructions.

content.prompt_es: Reescribe: 'If I were a richer man...'
content.stimulus_en: If I were a richer man, I'd retire.
content.correct_answer: Were I a richer man, I'd retire.
content.explanation: Second conditional inversion with 'be'.

content.prompt_es: Enfatiza el verbo usando el auxiliar 'do':
content.stimulus_en: I believe you.
content.correct_answer: I do believe you.
content.explanation: Emphatic 'do' is used in affirmative sentences for focus.

content.stimulus_en: She called him yesterday.
content.correct_answer: She did call him yesterday.
content.explanation: Use 'did' + base form for past emphasis.

options.text: Into the room walked the president.
The president walked into the room.

content.correct_answer: o1
content.explanation: Fronting moves an adverbial or prepositional phrase to the start.

content.stimulus_en: The view was beautiful.
content.correct_answer: Beautiful was the view.
content.explanation: Adjectives can be fronted for literary effect.

content.prompt_es: Completa con el auxiliar de énfasis:
content.stimulus_en: He ________ look tired today, doesn't he?
content.correct_answer: does
content.explanation: Emphatic 'does' for third person singular.

options.text: So cold was the night that we couldn't sleep.
The night was so cold that we couldn't sleep.

content.correct_answer: a
content.explanation: 'So + adjective' fronting requires inversion.

content.stimulus_en: I disagree with you.
content.correct_answer: I do disagree with you.
content.explanation: Emphatic 'do' for contrasting opinions.

content.stimulus_en: The castle stands on the hill.
content.correct_answer: On the hill stands the castle.
content.explanation: Prepositional phrase fronting with a verb of position.

content.stimulus_en: ________ a mess you've made!
content.correct_answer: What
content.explanation: 'What' + noun phrase for exclamation.

options.text: Such was his power that everyone feared him.
His power was such that everyone feared him.

content.correct_answer: o1
content.explanation: 'Such' can be fronted for emphasis, requiring inversion.

content.stimulus_en: He didn't realize his mistake until later.
content.correct_answer: Not until later did he realize his mistake.
content.explanation: 'Not until' phrases at the beginning trigger inversion in the main clause.

content.stimulus_en: The weather delayed the flight.
content.correct_answer: What delayed the flight was the weather.
content.explanation: Cleft sentence focusing on the subject.

options.text: Hardly had I arrived when the phone rang.
I had hardly arrived when the phone rang.

content.correct_answer: a
content.explanation: Inversion provides a more dramatic and sophisticated tone.

content.stimulus_en: You can solve this problem only by working hard.
content.correct_answer: Only by working hard can you solve this problem.
content.explanation: 'Only by' requires inversion of the modal/auxiliary.

content.stimulus_en: It was John ________ told me the news.
content.correct_answer: who
content.explanation: Use 'who' or 'that' for people in cleft sentences.

content.stimulus_en: I have never seen such a disaster before.
content.correct_answer: Never before have I seen such a disaster.
content.explanation: Inversion with negative frequency adverbial.

options.text: Were it not for your help, I would have failed.
Were not it for your help, I would have failed.

content.correct_answer: o1
content.explanation: Standard formal structure for 'If it weren't for...'.

content.stimulus_en: I want some peace and quiet.
content.correct_answer: All I want is some peace and quiet.
content.explanation: Pseudo-cleft with 'All'.

content.prompt_es: Completa con la inversión de 'Only after':
content.stimulus_en: Only after the show ________ we get to meet the actors.
content.correct_answer: did
content.explanation: The second clause in 'Only after...' phrases is inverted.

content.prompt_es: Finaliza con una 'What-cleft' para enfatizar 'your honesty':
content.stimulus_en: I appreciate your honesty.
content.correct_answer: What I appreciate is your honesty.
content.explanation: Simple What-cleft for emphasis.
